blocks.title: The title of this section
paragraphs: The program traditionally called 'Hello, world!' is very simple. It outputs the phrase 'Hello, world!' or something similar using the features of a particular programming language.

JavaScript is a language whose programs can be executed in different environments. In our case, we are talking about browsers and the server-side platform Node.js. If you haven’t written a single line of JS code yet and are reading this text in a browser on a desktop computer, it means you are literally seconds away from your first JavaScript program.

There are also other ways to run JS code in a browser. For example, in typical use, JavaScript programs are loaded into the browser to enable web page functionality. Usually, the code is written in separate files with the .js extension, which are then linked to web pages, but the code can also be included directly within the page itself. This is done using the <script> tag. When the browser encounters such code, it executes it. You can find more details about the <script> tag on w3schools.com. In particular, consider the example demonstrating how to work with a web page using JavaScript, provided on that site. You can run this example directly on the site (look for the Try it Yourself button), but we will take a slightly different approach. Specifically, we will create a new file in a text editor (for example, VS Code or Notepad++), name it hello.html, and add the following code to it:
